snippet: The Supreme Court of Cassation threw out the conviction of a homeless Ukrainian who tried to steal cheese and sausage, saying he acted “in a state of need.”
abstract: Italy's highest court throws out conviction of homeless man Roman Ostriakov on charges of trying to steal food from supermarket, ruling theft of food motivated by extreme need does not constitute crime.

byline.original: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and SEWELL CHAN
byline.contributor: Gaia Pianigiani reported from Rome, and Sewell Chan from London.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of Cassation threw out the conviction of a homeless Ukrainian who tried to steal cheese and sausage, saying he acted “in a state of need.”

headline.main: Can the Homeless and Hungry Steal Food? Maybe, an Italian Court Says
headline.print_headline: Food Theft by Italy’s Homeless and Hungry May Not Be a Crime, Court Says
